Toen de hongerige Gauruk Gest Ganest aanviel, at hij alleen de brandende wind van de tovenaar op - een mondvol wonden. Weinigen weten nu hoe je de onzichtbare geest van de verschroeiende wind aan de messen kunt binden en hoe je hem tientallen of zelfs eeuwen lang kunt laten meegaan, en als er al een manier was om de constructies te beheersen, is die kennis verloren gegaan.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Verschroeiende winden zijn gedachteloos en er is geen strategie in hun aanvallen. In plaats daarvan blijven zij iedereen aanvallen die de ruimte binnenkomt die zij moeten beschermen, en achtervolgen hen alleen als hun orders erop staan om alle vijanden te vernietigen.

trait.name: Constrict
entries: De slingerplant gebruikt een bonusactie om 5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) vernietigende schade toe te brengen aan alle {@condition grappled} wezens. De slinger heeft 1 ranken voor elke 20 hit points, afgerond naar beneden. Hij begint met 5 ranken en verliest of krijgt nieuwe ranken als hij schade oploopt of weer hit points krijgt.

trait.name: Vitality Drain (Recharge 5-6)
entries: De slangenwortel kan een bonusactie gebruiken om elk wezen binnen een straal van 10 meter te verminken met 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotische schade. Het doelwit moet slagen op een {@dc 10} grondwettelijke reddingsworp of zijn maximale aantal hitpoints wordt verminderd met een bedrag dat gelijk is aan de opgelopen schade, en de slingerwortel wordt geheeld met een gelijk bedrag. Deze reductie duurt tot het wezen een lange rustpauze beëindigt. Het doelwit sterft als dit effect zijn maximale aantal hitpoints tot 0 reduceert.

action.name: Tendril Lash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} om te raken, reikwijdte 10 ft., één doelwit. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage en het doelwit wordt {@condition grappled} (ontsnapt {@dc 12}, met nadeel indien {@condition grappled} door 2 of meer ranken). De liaan moet ten minste één vrije ranken hebben om een aanval uit te voeren.

Er groeit een dicht bladerdek met diepgroene bladeren met platte bladen en trossen knobbelige bruine wortels die zich door de onmiddellijke omgeving verspreiden. Als een schepsel nadert, beven de wortels en beginnen ze te kronkelen, op zoek naar een nieuwe prooi.

entries.name: Living Weapon
entries: Slangenwortel groeit van nature in het Hornsawoud, waar het een bedreiging vormt voor zowel bezoekers als bewoners. De tovenaar Anteas, hoofdadviseur van koning Virduk, was de eerste die de plant als wapen gebruikte. Hij transplanteerde op een of andere manier een wortel naar de IJzertandpas, en de zich snel verspreidende plant vernietigde het fort en zijn dwergenbewoners binnen veertien dagen.

entries.name: Invasive Species
entries: Sindsdien is overal op het Ghelspad Slangenwortel gesignaleerd en het lijkt snel te groeien. Als je er niet in slaagt om zelfs het kleinste stukje volledig te vernietigen, kan het zich binnen enkele dagen opnieuw verspreiden en een bedreiging vormen. Volwassen plekken zenden ondergrondse wortels uit en nieuwe kind-patches van serpent root kunnen tot 300 voet ver van hun ouder groeien.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Serpent root toont geen tactisch inzicht, maar grijpt gewoon iedereen die dichtbij is en probeert ze te doden met zijn verstikkende ranken. Het zal zijn vitaliteit drain gebruiken zodra het schade oploopt en wanneer het daarna kan.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: Als bonusactie kan de shackledeath zich tot zijn snelheid naar een vijandig wezen bewegen dat hij kan zien.

trait.name: Punishment
entries: De shackledeath kan zijn bonusactie gebruiken om elk schepsel te straffen dat hij geboeid heeft. Het effect hangt af van het aantal manakels dat elk wezen draagt:

items: {@i 1 manacle:} het doelwit neemt {@damage 1d8} necrotische schade op en kan geen hit points terugkrijgen tot het begin van de volgende beurt van de shackledeath.
{@i 2 manacles:} het doelwit neemt {@damage 3d6} necrotische schade op en de shackledeath krijgt tijdelijke hit points gelijk aan de opgelopen schade.
{@i 3 manacles:} krijgt het doelwit een level van {@condition exhaustion} en herstelt de shackledeath al zijn hit points.
{@i 4 manacles:} het doelwit krijgt 61 ({@damage 7d8 + 30}) necrotische schade.

entries: Als een schepsel door deze macht wordt gedood, wordt het een {@creature zombie} onder de controle van de shackledeath.

action.name: Shackle
entries: Melee Weapon Attack. {@hit 8} om te raken, bereik 5 ft., één doelwit. {@h} het doelwit wordt gevangen door één manakel (ontsnapping {@dc 20}). De shackledeath heeft een totaal van 4 manakels. Manakels sluiten op magische wijze de ledematen van een doelwit. Als een shackledeath wordt gedood, gaan de manakels open.

Gemakkelijk te verwarren met ondoden, zijn shackledeaths eigenlijk buiten-planaire wezens in dienst van Chardun. Ze lijken op grote, mensachtige skeletten met groen oplichtende ogen. Hun sleutelbeenderen zijn abnormaal lang en dik en strekken zich uit tot ongeveer een meter van elke schouder. Aan elk van deze sleutelbeenderen hangen twee kettingen, elk ongeveer een meter lang. Deze kettingen eindigen in boeien of kluisters van zwart ijzer. Shackledeaths dragen soms de haveloze overblijfselen van wat eens gewaden van geestelijken van Chardun geweest kunnen zijn. Ze lopen met een schamele tred die hun snelheid en behendigheid verraadt.

entries.name: The Will of Chardun
entries: Shackledeaths dwingen de wil van Chardun in de sterfelijke wereld af en treden op als handhavers en beulen van mensen die de god beledigen of hun plichten jegens hem verzaken. Ze worden vaak gezonden om te straffen in plaats van te doden; Chardun is een godheid van onderdrukking in plaats van moedwillige slachting. De overtreders behouden hun leven en weten wat hen te wachten staat als ze opnieuw falen. Het is mogelijk dat echt vrome of ijverige volgelingen van Chardun de dienst en hulp van slavendrijvers hebben gekregen, en hen als bewakers houden. De Slaver is echter bijzonder waakzaam voor deze gezegende volgelingen. Zij mogen dan prominent zijn onder zijn volgelingen, maar zij hebben ook meer te duchten als zij uit de gratie vallen. Chardun duldt geen sympathie of medelijden onder zijn elite en verwacht dat zijn boeien in dienst van zulke overlopers straf zullen uitdelen.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Shackledeaths hebben gewoonlijk meer te maken met verlammen of intimideren dan met het toebrengen van dodelijke verwondingen. Zij deinzen er echter niet voor terug om te doden als zij dat nodig achten, bijvoorbeeld als een volgeling van Chardun zijn verdiende straf ontloopt. Shackledeaths zijn fanatiek toegewijd aan hun werk en trekken zich niet terug, tenzij ze voor een totale nederlaag staan. In dat geval zijn zij intelligent genoeg om terug te vallen en zich te hergroeperen, zij zoeken altijd naar alternatieve manieren om hun missies te volbrengen en houden hun slachtoffer desnoods hun hele natuurlijke leven in de gaten en volgen hem.

trait.name: Gift of Tongues
entries: De schaduwraaf kan de letterlijke betekenis begrijpen van elke gesproken taal die hij hoort.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: De schaduwraaf kan zich door andere wezens en voorwerpen bewegen alsof het moeilijk begaanbaar terrein is. Hij ontvangt 5 ({@damage 1d10}) krachtschade als hij zijn beurt eindigt in een voorwerp.

trait.name: Light Sensitivity
entries: In fel licht heeft de schaduwraaf nadeel bij aanvalsrollen en bij wijsheidscontroles (waarneming) die op zicht gebaseerd zijn.

trait.name: Shadow Sight
entries: Magische duisternis belemmert het zicht van de schaduw raaf niet.

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: In schemerlicht of duisternis kan de schaduwraaf de actie Verbergen als bonusactie uitvoeren.

action.name: Strength Drain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doelwit. {@h}1 necrotische schade, en de Strength score van het doelwit wordt gereduceerd met {@dice 1d3}. Het doelwit wordt {@condition unconscious} als dit zijn kracht tot 0 vermindert. Anders duurt de vermindering tot het doelwit een korte of lange rust beëindigt.

Schaduwraven verduisteren soms de lucht van Scarn. Het is zelfs mogelijk dat hun aantal is toegenomen sinds ze werden geschapen, lang voor de Titanenoorlog. Hun angstaanjagende, schrille kreten zijn 's nachts vaak te horen. Men kan grote groepen schaduwraven zien overvliegen of bomen omhangen bij belangrijke bijeenkomsten of gebeurtenissen van de verschillende sterfelijke rassen.

Een schaduw raaf is een grote, maar vreemd onduidelijke vogel, misschien 18 centimeter hoog, maar gehuld in duisternis. Bloedrode ogen glinsteren in de plooien van middernacht die zijn vorm vormen, en zijn vleugels zijn niet veel meer dan schaduwflarden.

entries.name: Spawn of Golthain
entries: Lang voor zijn gevangenschap door de goden, maar na het begin van de Goddelijke Oorlog, toen hij gestraft werd door zijn mede titanen, veranderde Golthain de Gezichtloze alledaagse vogels in deze wezens. Schaduwraven, ook bekend als de "Ogen van Golthain", of anders de "Oren van Golthain", werden de spionnen van de titaan in de buitenwereld. Overal waar zijn invloed werd uitgeoefend, was een zwerm schaduwraven te vinden.

entries.name: Gatherers of News and Lore
entries: Als het mogelijk is dat de Gezichtenloze nog steeds informatie ontvangt van zijn schepsels, of als deze schepsels nu een nieuwe meester dienen, dan zou dat wezen wel eens het best geïnformeerd kunnen zijn over belangrijke zaken in de Scarred Lands. Er zijn al lang verhalen bekend van tovenaars die op de een of andere manier een schaduwraaf als vertrouweling kregen, hoewel onbekend is hoe men dat zou kunnen doen. "Laat de oren van Golthain u niet horen" blijft een populair gezegde in sommige streken, een herinnering aan discretie wanneer geheimen worden verteld of privézaken worden besproken.

entries.name: Creatures of Darkness
entries: Schaduwraven houden niet van fel licht; plotselinge flitsen kunnen hen afschrikken, althans voor een tijdje.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Schaduwraven vallen gewoonlijk geen andere wezens aan; hun rol is te verzamelen en te observeren, en dan verslag uit te brengen aan hun meester. Solitaire schaduwraven, of zelfs kleine zwermen, proberen altijd aan aanvallers te ontkomen in plaats van terug te vechten. Zelfs als een grote zwerm wordt aangevallen, vliegt ze meestal weg. Als een zwerm schaduwraven geen uitweg heeft, kunnen ze aanvallers in een zwerm aanvallen, waarbij ze onstoffelijke snavels gebruiken om de aanvallers uit te schakelen voordat ze wegvliegen.

trait.name: Brainfood
entries: Als een slachtoffer eenmaal geïnfecteerd is (zie hieronder) komen de eieren binnen 24 uur uit en moet de gastheer een {@dc 11} grondwetsredding doen tegen de ziekte of {@condition poisoned} worden totdat de doodshoofdwormen zijn verwijderd. Elk uur dat daarna verstrijkt, moet het wezen de reddingsworp herhalen, waarbij zijn intelligentie- en wijsheidsscore elk met 2 ({@dice 1d4}) worden verlaagd als het niet slaagt. Deze vermindering duurt tot de Skullworms verwijderd zijn. Als de Intelligentie- of Wijsheidsscore van het wezen tot 0 is verlaagd, is het {@condition incapacitated} voor {@dice 1d4} uur. Na die tijd ontwaakt het en zijn Intelligentie- en Wijsheidsscore zijn weer hersteld tot hun normale waarden; de doodshoofdwormen beheersen nu echter het lichaam van het wezen, hoewel ze het bewustzijn niet van het doelwit ontnemen.

trait.name: Hidden Hunters
entries: Schedelwormen liggen op de loer in stilstaand water en andere plaatsen waar de dood heerst. Ze kunnen worden opgemerkt door avonturiers met een {@dc 10} Intelligentie (Onderzoek), Wijsheid (Waarneming), of Wijsheid (Overleving) check. Een wezen dat de skullworms opmerkt, kan hun aanvallen ontwijken.

action.name: Infect
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} om te raken, bereik 0 ft., één doelwit. {@h} het doelwit wordt besmet, zie Brainfood hierboven.

Schedelwormen zijn wormachtig ongedierte, ongeveer een halve centimeter lang op ware grootte. Ze zijn gemaakt door Chern de Gesel en leven in warme, vochtige, onooglijke plaatsen zoals moerassen, riolen, vuilnishopen en open graven. Vaak brengt een levend wezen dat in hun hol rondsnuffelt per ongeluk een of meer doodskopwormen over op zijn lichaam. De wormen zoeken dan een warme plek op het schepsel, wachten tot hun gastheer slaapt of anderszins inert is, en dringen dan het slachtoffer binnen via een van zijn schedelopeningen. Eenmaal binnen in de kop van het wezen, leggen ze eitjes voordat ze sterven. De eitjes komen {@dice 4d6} uur later uit, en de larven beginnen vezels te weven in de synapsen van het slachtoffer.

Elk effect dat een ziekte geneest, doodt alle skullwormen of niet uitgekomen eieren in of op een gastheer. Een wezen dat al bezeten is door de doodskopwormen zakt in elkaar en is {@condition incapacitated} permanent, effectief hersendood. Alleen een {@spell regenerate}, {@spell wish}, of soortgelijke krachtige magie kan het wezen op dit punt herstellen.

entries.name: Malevolent Corrupters
entries: Het ware doel van de skullworm is het lichaam van andere levende wezens binnen te dringen en hun geest te controleren. Zodra de larven van de doodskopworm zich in de hersenen nestelen, beginnen zij het bewustzijn van het slachtoffer te vervangen door een fragment van de kwaadaardige wil van Chern. De larven hebben beperkte toegang tot de herinneringen van de gastheer en gebruiken die om hun gedrag bijna exact te kopiëren. Bij de dood van hun gastheer, of als ze de gastheer om een andere reden ongeschikt vinden, kruipen de volwassen doodskopwormen naar buiten om een nieuwe gastheer te zoeken.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Geleidelijk aan corrumperen en vernietigen de Skullworms wat de gastheer ooit dierbaar was, meestal op de wreedst mogelijke manieren. Het slachtoffer is zich pijnlijk bewust van wat zijn lichaam doet, maar is in wezen een toeschouwer, niet in staat iets te voorkomen, wat misschien wel de ergste kwelling van allemaal is. Een worm kan jarenlang de controle over een gastheer behouden, tenzij hij op magische wijze wordt ontdekt of tenzij iemand die de persoon kent, zich realiseert dat hij zich anders gedraagt dan hij zou willen en mogelijk tegen zijn wil in. De wormen dwingen het slachtoffer uiteindelijk zijn familie en vrienden te doden en zijn eigen beste prestaties te vernietigen.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Een skyquill kan van nature de volgende spreuken uitspreken, waarvoor geen materiële componenten nodig zijn:

trait.name: Adhesive Glands
entries: De handen en voeten van een skyquill hebben grijs-zwarte klieren die een kleefstof uitstralen waarmee ze muren en plafonds kunnen beklimmen. Een wezen dat een skyquill probeert te duwen heeft nadeel bij de check.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doel. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d4 + 6}) knuppelschade.

action.name: Quills
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} om te raken, bereik 20/60 ft., één doelwit. {@h}{@dice 1d6} willekeurige kleur stekels:

rows: Het doelwit moet een {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw doen of {@condition charmed} worden door een willekeurig wezen binnen 60 ft. van het doelwit. Het doelwit spendeert zijn beurt om te proberen dat wezen te helpen. De conditie duurt tot het wezen het doelwit aanvalt of tot er 1 minuut voorbij is.

Het doelwit wordt overmand door razende honger. Als het aan de beurt is, zal het proberen wat voedsel te eten. Als dat niet lukt, krijgt het een level van {@condition exhaustion}. Het effect eindigt dan.

Het doelwit wordt overmand door brandende dorst. Als het aan de beurt is, zal het proberen wat water of een andere veilige vloeistof te drinken. Als dat niet lukt, krijgt het een level van {@condition exhaustion}. Het effect eindigt dan.

Het doelwit moet een {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw doen of {@condition stunned} gefixeerd raken op een onschadelijk voorwerp in zijn onmiddellijke omgeving. Het brengt zijn beurt door met interactie met dat voorwerp. De toestand duurt 1 minuut en hij mag de worp herhalen aan het einde van zijn beurt.

Het doelwit moet een {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw doen of het wordt {@condition frightened} van alle vijandige wezens in zicht. De conditie duurt 1 minuut en het mag de reddende worp herhalen aan het einde van zijn beurt.
Het doelwit moet een {@dc 13} grondwettelijke worp doen of {@condition unconscious} worden. Een wezen kan een actie gebruiken om het doelwit te wekken.

entries: De wolkenkrabben hebben een mengeling van insectachtige en mensachtige trekken, met slanke lichamen, veelzijdige ogen, vlinderachtige vleugels, en een staart die spits toeloopt in een cluster van regenboogkleurige stekels. Als ze rechtop staan, zijn ze even lang als een elf of een mens, maar ze buigen vaak voorover, over de bloeiende struiken en de veelkleurige vlinders die ze begeleiden.

entries.name: Acolytes of Syhana
entries: Hemelkrekels zijn de kinderen van Syhana, halfgodin van de wolken, dochter van Madriel, godin van de hemel. Zij zijn belast met het verzorgen en cultiveren van wolken en regen. De hemelkieuwen vliegen tussen de wolken en geven ze vorm. Er wordt ook gezegd dat ze de regenboogpaden bewandelen en weten wat er aan het einde ligt.

entries.name: The Secret of the Quillflies
entries: Parelmoervlinders bewaren een zorgvuldig bewaard geheim: onder het gewone vlindervolk zitten quillflies, makers van een magische nectar die wolken met regen kan bezaaien. Skyquills zijn dan ook beschermend tegenover hun vlinderzwermen en hun geheime leden. Ze zijn vaak dicht bij de grond te vinden, waar ze voor de quillflies zorgen en de magische nectar verzamelen.

entries.name: The Gift of the Skyquills
entries: Veel boeren in de Scarred Lands geven oude spreekwoorden door die zeggen dat het taboe is om vlinders te doden, omdat ze anders droogte over het land brengen. Andere legenden vertellen over een hooggeboren dame die veel vlinderstruiken rond haar landhuis plantte, waardoor ze in de achting van de hemelkrekels kwam te staan, en haar velden nooit om een verfrissende regenbui verlegen zaten.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Skyquills vluchten liever dan dat ze vechten, maar ze zullen hun kuddes wel beschermen. Ze zullen hun stekels afschieten op indringers, in de hoop zo een afleiding te veroorzaken. Ze zullen {@spell color spray} en {@spell fog cloud} gebruiken om de verwarring van hun vijanden te vergroten. Alleen in de meest wanhopige gevallen zullen ze hun slam aanval gebruiken.

resist.note: from weapons that are not magical or adamantine

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: Het huisdier van de slavenhandelaar is immuun voor elke spreuk of effect dat zijn vorm zou veranderen.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Het huisdier van de slavenhandelaar heeft voordeel bij het opslaan van worpen tegen spreuken en andere magische effecten.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: Het huisdier van de slavendrijver kan op moeilijke oppervlakken klimmen, ook ondersteboven op het plafond, zonder dat hij een vaardigheidscontrole hoeft te doen.

trait.name: Unwavering
entries: Het huisdier van de slavenhandelaar kan niet worden afgeleid en heeft voordeel bij alle passieve waarnemingscontroles.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Het huisdier van de slavendrijver voert vier aanvallen uit met een combinatie van kettingklauw- en slamaanvallen.

action.name: Chain Claw
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} om te raken, bereik 20/40 ft., één doelwit. {@h} het doelwit is {@condition grappled} (ontsnapping {@dc 21}) en wordt gedwongen te bewegen wanneer het huisdier van de slavendrijver beweegt. Een gecontroleerd slavenhuisdier beweegt nooit sneller dan de snelheid van zijn langzaamste {@condition grappled} wezen.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doelwit. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) knuppelschade en het schepsel moet een {@dc 17} Sterkte-overlevingsworp doen of 20 voet worden gegooid, waarbij het {@condition prone} landt.

action.name: Shock
entries: Als actie kan het huisdier van de slavenhandelaar een schok sturen naar elk wezen dat hij {@condition grappled} heeft. Het wezen ontvangt 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bliksemschade en moet een {@dc 15} grondwetsredding maken of {@condition unconscious} worden voor 1 minuut.

De naderende vorm is die van een grote metalen spin met lange, veelarmige poten. Een wirwar van kettingen die eindigen in geklauwde metalen handen wervelt om hem heen, en het schepsel klettert naar voren met een duidelijk vijandige bedoeling.

entries.name: Charduni Raider
entries: Het huisdier van de slavenhandelaar is een constructie ontwikkeld door tovenaars van Charduni om te helpen bij slavenrooftochten. Het lijkt op een grote ijzeren spin met acht lange, spichtige poten. Op het kruispunt van de acht poten bevindt zich een massa opgerolde kettingen met daarop vier scherp geklauwde, geanimeerde handen. Het bouwsel kan deze handen uitschieten, die aan het lichaam blijven vastzitten door een 40 voet lange ketting die vanuit het centrale punt afrolt. Het huisdier van de slavenhandelaar grijpt toekomstige slaven of andere slachtoffers in wie de Charduni enige belangstelling hebben, en houdt ze vast.

entries.name: Pilot's Seat
entries: Hoewel het huisdier van de slavendrijver is ontworpen om autonoom te zijn, is het uitgerust met een beklede stoel waarop een Charduni controleur kan zitten en zijn bewegingen en acties kan sturen. Deze constructie kan worden gebruikt om moeilijk begaanbaar terrein te doorkruisen, maar er zijn er nog maar weinig over en nog minder tovenaars die ze kunnen en willen maken. De Charduni zijn begrijpelijkerwijs terughoudend om hun kostbare machines nodeloos op het spel te zetten.

entries.name: Rogue Machines
entries: Er wordt verondersteld dat er een paar huisdieren van slavendrijvers in Termana rondzwerven, verdwaald en gedachteloos de laatste bevelen van hun meesters opvolgend - onschuldigen gevangennemend, hen vastbindend en met hen meeslepend tot ze sterven van de honger of van blootstelling.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Bij het vangen van slaven let het huisdier van de slavendrijver erop alleen niet-dodelijke schade toe te brengen aan de doelen. Potentiële slaven worden gevangen door de kettingklauwen, ongewenste slaven worden weggevaagd door de spinachtige poten. Als het dier nog goed geprogrammeerd is, maar zonder besturing, keert het terug met zijn gevangen slaven door zich te verplaatsen met een snelheid die zij kunnen aanhouden. Rogue pets hebben deze programmering verloren en kunnen hun topsnelheid aanhouden, ongeacht wat er met de gevangen schepsels gebeurt. Sommigen slepen de doden mee tot ze een betere kandidaat vinden, die waarschijnlijk hetzelfde lot zal ondergaan.

De ketting die een slaaf met zijn huisdier verbindt kan worden verbroken - daarvoor moet die ketting tenminste 25 punten zuur-, hak- of knuppelschade oplopen (let op de weerstanden en immuniteiten hierboven).

trait.name: Frozen Body
entries: Een wezen dat de sneeuwduivel aanraakt of hem raakt met een melee aanval binnen een straal van 5 meter van de duivel, krijgt 3 ({@damage 1d6}) koude schade.

trait.name: Sense Heat
entries: The sleet devil can sense the presence of creatures whose temperature differs significantly from their surroundings and has advantage on perception checks to detect them.

trait.name: Sleet Cloud
entries: A constantly swirling vortex of ice surrounds the sleet devil, and creatures using normal vision or darkvision to see the devil have disadvantage on their attack rolls.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sleet devil makes two claw attacks and a bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage. Miss: 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

From a distance, the sleet devil appears as a cloud of ice and snow, swirling in a wind that seemingly arose without warning. Those brave enough to approach may see a shadow moving within the cloud and catch a glimpse of glowing ice-blue eyes. Once inside the storm, a long serpentine body, nearly 60 feet long, can be seen, with two long, clawed forelimbs made of ice itself. The creature's long jaw is filled with icicle teeth, hard and sharp.

entries.name: Icy Devil
entries: During the severe winters of the northlands, the locals huddle indoors around their fires and tell tales of fell things that stalk the night, waiting to catch and slay anyone they find. At least one of these tales is true: the sleet devil. The malicious creature hunts during the coldest nights, searching for warm things to kill out of spite.

entries.name: Titanspawn
entries: Legends abound regarding the sleet devil, some have it as spawned by the anger of lost travelers or a manifestation of the cruel winter itself. But some of the wise say that the presence of the creature proves that one of the titans must be buried beneath the ice at the top of the world.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Sleet devils often lie buried under snow banks to ambush opponents, though they are also fond of openly and slowly approaching lone travelers to heighten their prey's sense of dread. If a sleet devil judges it can toy with its opponents, it will do so. But if the prey fights back then they go for the kill, focusing on less dangerous targets first. If the combat turns against them, sleet devils will flee, perhaps to set a trap and get their revenge later.

trait.name: Bone Armor
entries: Slime reavers wear armor made of giant turtle shells and other bony plates. On a critical hit, the bone armor is destroyed but absorbs all damage dealt. The slime reaver's AC then becomes 12.

trait.name: Leap
entries: The swamp reaver can use its bonus action to leap in the air, up to 10 feet in the air and 20 feet forward in the direction that it was facing. If it lands next to an opponent and makes a successful attack roll, the attack counts as a critical hit.

trait.name: Swamp Camouflage
entries: The slime reaver has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in marshes or watery terrain.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: Slime reavers are amphibian and can breathe air and water.

action.name: Dart
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage and the target must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of the slime reaver's next turn.

action.name: Net
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 5/15 ft., one target. {@h}a Large or smaller creature is {@condition restrained} by the net. A creature can use its action to make a {@dc 10} Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within reach on a success.
Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) destroys the net and releases the target.

action.name: Poisoned Short-Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage and the target must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of the slime reaver's next turn.

variant.name: Slime Reaver Spell casters
entries: A few slime reavers are druids, and have the following feature:

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: The slime reaver is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 11}, {@hit 3} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following druid spells prepared:

items: Cantrips (at will): {@spell mending}, {@spell poison spray}
1st level spells (4/day): {@spell entangle}, {@spell faerie fire}
2nd level spells (2/day): {@spell hold person}, {@spell pass without trace}

entries: Slime reaver spellcasters are Challenge 2.

Slime reavers are amphibious froglike humanoids that inhabit many of the Scarred Land's marshes, swamps and freshwater lakes. Slime reavers occasionally battle with the Slitheren in the Mourning Marshes, but are equally known to trade with them. The reavers also make frequent slaving raids against the frontier settlements of Vesh that lie in or near the marsh. Reavers worship several titans, most notably Chern and Gulaben. Slime reaver druids usually have some sort of shrine to these and other titans.

entries.name: Slave Rings
entries: Slavery is not only tolerated in slime reaver culture, it is encouraged. Those with ‘landspawn' slaves have the highest reputation and many slime reaver villages own one or more slaver rings, a {@i ring of water breathing} designed so that the wearer cannot breathe air while wearing it. Each set of rings has a master ring, if the slave ventures too far from the master's location the ring fails utterly and the slave drowns.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Slime reavers excel at guerilla warfare. They rise from reeds or shallow water, attacking the most dangerous foes with nets and darts before closing in for the kill. Those reavers not involved in combat concentrate on netting and capturing anyone who looks like slave material. Spellcasters assist from afar. If a battle starts going against them, they quickly retreat with whatever they can, diving underwater where most opponents cannot follow. Slave-rings are placed on the captured, and all return to the tribe.

trait.name: Contortionist
entries: The slitherin has advantage on Dexterity checks to escape from bonds or being {@condition grappled}, as well as to squeeze through tight spaces.

trait.name: Disease Resistance
entries: The slitherin has advantage on saving throws against disease.

trait.name: Rodent Empathy
entries: The slitherin can converse with rodents through body language and simple sounds, communicating simple ideas to such beasts.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The slitherin makes one bite attack and one shortsword attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d3 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage.

entries.name: Unredeemed Slitherin
entries: Slitherin were referred to during the Divine War as the "scourge of the underrealm." Today, those ratfolk who still follow the titans and the old ways lurk yet in the dark corners of the Scarred Lands. The Redeemed slitherin of the Scarred Lands often call their debased titanspawn cousins "ratlings," a term of contempt.

entries.name: Cultists and Fanatics
entries: Led by their druidic priest-kings, the various clans of Unredeemed slitherin are each a pale and twisted reflection of the titan upon whose essence they once fed. They are a superstitious people, filled with a burning fear of starvation and of their dark titanic masters, a fear kept at a fever pitch by the priesthood. Prayers are made twice daily to the priest-king for his intercession with the titans, and the slitherin year is filled with holy days and rituals. In fact, each tribe observes its own calendar of tribute events, and any commingling of ratfolk from different nests demands honoring the holy days of all participants.

entries.name: Social Creatures
entries: Slitherin are known to bolster their forces by calling upon packs of giant rats and swarms of normal rats to join them in battle. When led by their priests, rat-folk are capable of organized warfare and can use their great numbers to deadly effect. Lone ratfolk usually attempt to flee from conflict, but they can be driven into a fury if cornered. They fight only when in a group, preferably with three-to-one odds or better and from ambush.

entries.name: Slitherin
entries: The common slitherin here represents a common ratfolk warrior, guard, or cultist that could be encountered almost anywhere in the Scarred Lands, having no particular clan affiliation. To better emulate a slitherin from a particular clan, add one or two appropriate clan abilities or features (borrowed from the sample statistics for the various slitherin clans, below).
Most ratfolk encountered away from their burrows or nests are warriors. Like their clothing, their armor and weapons are typically pitted and caked with filth.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Slitherin use their contortionist and climb abilities to occupy areas that it is hard for their targets to reach. From this relative safety they take repeated shots at their enemy, until they are slain or retreat. If forced into melee combat they engage only long enough to lead their opponents into another cluster of hidden slitherin or bolt from combat at the first opportunity.

entries.name: Slitherin Clans
entries: There are numerous clans or sub-species of ratfolk titans-pawn, such as the Brown Gorgers, the Diseased, and the Red Witches. In general, each clan has traits and abilities that align it with one of the fallen titans. Information and typical stats for representative members of the {@creature diseased slitherin|SLCC|Diseased}, the {@creature dunewalker slitherin|SLCC|Dunewalkers}, the {@creature foamer|SLCC|Foamers}, and the {@creature red witch|SLCC|Red Witches} appear here.

trait.name: Contortionist
entries: The slitherin has advantage on Dexterity checks to escape from bonds or being {@condition grappled}, as well as to squeeze through tight spaces.

trait.name: Disease Carrier
entries: The Diseased slitherin is immune to the effects of disease. However, it can still contract diseases and be a carrier, exposing others to the disease's ravages.

trait.name: Rodent Empathy
entries: The slitherin can converse with rodents through body language and simple sounds, communicating simple ideas to such beasts.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The slitherin makes two attacks: one bite and one claw, or one bite and one shortsword.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d3 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw against disease or become {@condition poisoned} until the disease is cured. Every 24 hours that elapse, the creature must repeat the saving throw, reducing its hit point maximum by 3 ({@dice 1d6}) on a failure. This reduction lasts until the disease is cured. The creature dies if the disease reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doelwit. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) doorborende schade.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

entries.name: Unredeemed Slitherin
entries: Slitherin were referred to during the Divine War as the "scourge of the underrealm." Today, those ratfolk who still follow the titans and the old ways lurk yet in the dark corners of the Scarred Lands. In fact, each tribe observes its own calendar of tribute events, and any commingling of ratfolk from different nests demands honoring the holy days of all participants.

entries.name: Social Creatures

When led by their priests, rat-folk are capable of organized warfare and can use their great numbers to deadly effect. Lone ratfolk usually attempt to flee from conflict, but they can be driven into a fury if cornered. They fight only when in a group, preferably with three-to-one odds or better and from ambush.

entries.name: Diseased
entries: Those ratfolk that revere Chern the Unclean have formed some the most civilized of slitherin nests among the Unredeemed of their kind. Their settlements are often hidden beneath or within those of other races, though some above-ground communities exist in the Mourning Marshes, where Chern was interred.

The Diseased priesthood is divided into orders, each responsible for breeding slaves as hosts for different plagues and ailments. While rivalries exist among the orders, there is a limit to how far such conflicts can go; allowing a disease to die out would be considered an offense to Chern. Given their capacity for cooperation, the Diseased are the most likely slitherin to seek joint ventures with other nests, particularly when they require brute strength for their cunning plots.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The Diseased prefer to strike from stealth, with ranged weapons ideally, rather than attack directly in melee. They will use their crossbows and try to climb to areas that their enemies cannot easily reach. Once pressed into melee combat, they are vicious and make good use of their bite attacks to weaken their foes.

trait.name: Contortionist
entries: The slitherin has advantage on Dexterity checks to escape from bonds or being {@condition grappled}, as well as to squeeze through tight spaces.

trait.name: Disease Resistance
entries: The slitherin has advantage on saving throws against disease.

trait.name: Rodent Empathy
entries: The slitherin can converse with rodents through body language and simple sounds, communicating simple ideas to such beasts.

trait.name: Surprise Attack
entries: If the Dunewalker surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 3 ({@damage 1d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Dunewalker makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its spear, or two with its shortbow.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d3 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage if used in two hands.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage.

entries.name: Unredeemed Slitherin
entries: Slitherin were referred to during the Divine War as the "scourge of the underrealm." Today, those ratfolk who still follow the titans and the old ways lurk yet in the dark corners of the Scarred Lands. The Redeemed slitherin of the Scarred Lands often call their debased titanspawn cousins "ratlings," a term of contempt.

Prayers are made twice daily to the priest-king for his intercession with the titans, and the slitherin year is filled with holy days and rituals. In fact, each tribe observes its own calendar of tribute events, and any commingling of ratfolk from different nests demands honoring the holy days of all participants.

entries.name: Social Creatures
entries: Slitherin are known to bolster their forces by calling upon packs of giant rats and swarms of normal rats to join them in battle. When led by their priests, rat-folk are capable of organized warfare and can use their great numbers to deadly effect. Lone ratfolk usually attempt to flee from conflict, but they can be driven into a fury if cornered. They fight only when in a group, preferably with three-to-one odds or better and from ambush.

entries.name: Dunewalkers
entries: Dunewalkers stride under the burning sun of the wasteland in tribute to the titan Thulkas, whom they venerate. Their tribes gather around the smoldering embers that were scattered when Corean forged the Father of Fire into an arrow, before Tanil then fired the titan into the sun. Indeed, the Dunewalkers believe that all deserts of the Scarred Lands were created where such sparks landed, and they are found in most arid lands.

To this day, each tribe feeds Thulkas' fire by gathering all combustible materials they can find in the wastes and burning them in tribute to their master. Seasoned desert travelers who see scattered firelight on the night horizon know to avoid it. Although they will certainly attack travelers for food (that which they carry and the travelers themselves), the Dunewalkers' most cherished prizes are wagons, chests, and barrels—materials made of dense wood that can burn for a long time.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Dunewalkers are skilled predators, making astounding leaps over dunes to attack caravans, seemingly from out of nowhere. They can also burrow through the sand and spring upward from the ground.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The Foamer has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Contortionist
entries: The slitherin has advantage on Dexterity checks to escape from bonds or being {@condition grappled}, as well as to squeeze through tight spaces.

trait.name: Disease Resistance
entries: The slitherin has advantage on saving throws against disease.

trait.name: Rodent Empathy
entries: The slitherin can converse with rodents through body language and simple sounds, communicating simple ideas to such beasts.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d3 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d12 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

entries.name: Unredeemed Slitherin
entries: Slitherin were referred to during the Divine War as the "scourge of the underrealm." Today, those ratfolk who still follow the titans and the old ways lurk yet in the dark corners of the Scarred Lands. The Redeemed slitherin of the Scarred Lands often call their debased titanspawn cousins "ratlings," a term of contempt.

They are a superstitious people, filled with a burning fear of starvation and of their dark titanic masters, a fear kept at a fever pitch by the priesthood. Prayers are made twice daily to the priest-king for his intercession with the titans, and the slitherin year is filled with holy days and rituals. In fact, each tribe observes its own calendar of tribute events, and any commingling of ratfolk from different nests demands honoring the holy days of all participants.

entries.name: Social Creatures
entries: Slitherin are known to bolster their forces by calling upon packs of giant rats and swarms of normal rats to join them in battle. When led by their priests, rat-folk are capable of organized warfare and can use their great numbers to deadly effect. Lone ratfolk usually attempt to flee from conflict, but they can be driven into a fury if cornered. They fight only when in a group, preferably with three-to-one odds or better and from ambush.

entries.name: Foamers
entries: Foamers are the physically largest and most savage of the Unredeemed ratfolk. They are weaned on the hate-maddened blood of Kadum the Mountainshaker, and they live for battle and slaughter. Natural swimmers, they are the bane of the seas, churning up from the water, surrounded by packs of giant rats, to rend the life from the unprepared.

Instead of dwelling in tunnels, Foamers reside on bloodstained and half-sunken boats and ships they have captured, sometimes lashing them together as floating atolls. Lacking sailing skills, they rely on captured slaves to propel these makeshift craft, either by sail or oar. In addition to propelling the ships, slaves are used for any task that is not combat-related, as the ratfolk consider such chores beneath warriors.

The Foamer priesthood is composed of generals and admirals of warbands, with their massive, ogre-sized priest-king being the most bloodthirsty berserker of them all. His white fur is crusted black by the oceans of blood through which he has waded, and his mad eyes search always for new victims. As might be expected, Foamer rituals are based on blood and slaughter, often pitting captured humanoids against each other in battles to the death.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Foamers lose all control in combat, disdaining defense and preferring the satisfaction of slashing and biting their foes. If they use missiles at all, they throw javelins as they close with their targets. They are fond of siege engines for the mayhem they cause in extended campaigns. In most cases, they back down only when commanded to do so by their priest-king. Otherwise, they fight to the death.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Red Witch is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 13}, or {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). The Red Witch has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Contortionist
entries: The slitherin has advantage on Dexterity checks to escape from bonds or being {@condition grappled}, as well as to squeeze through tight spaces.

trait.name: Disease Resistance
entries: The slitherin has advantage on saving throws against disease.

trait.name: Rodent Empathy
entries: The slitherin can converse with rodents through body language and simple sounds, communicating simple ideas to such beasts.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d3 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doelwit. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) doorborende schade.

entries.name: Unredeemed Slitherin
entries: Slitherin were referred to during the Divine War as the "scourge of the underrealm." Today, those ratfolk who still follow the titans and the old ways lurk yet in the dark corners of the Scarred Lands. The Redeemed slitherin of the Scarred Lands often call their debased titanspawn cousins "ratlings," a term of contempt.

entries.name: Cultists and Fanatics
entries: Led by their druidic priest-kings, the various clans of Unredeemed slitherin are each a pale and twisted reflection of the titan upon whose essence they once fed. They are a superstitious people, filled with a burning fear of starvation and of their dark titanic masters, a fear kept at a fever pitch by the priesthood. Prayers are made twice daily to the priest-king for his intercession with the titans, and the slitherin year is filled with holy days and rituals. In fact, each tribe observes its own calendar of tribute events, and any commingling of ratfolk from different nests demands honoring the holy days of all participants.

entries.name: Social Creatures
entries: Slitherin are known to bolster their forces by calling upon packs of giant rats and swarms of normal rats to join them in battle. When led by their priests, rat-folk are capable of organized warfare and can use their great numbers to deadly effect. Lone ratfolk usually attempt to flee from conflict, but they can be driven into a fury if cornered. They fight only when in a group, preferably with three-to-one odds or better and from ambush.

entries.name: Red Witches
entries: Those ratfolk who gorge upon the flesh of Mormo are the most terrifying and inscrutable of their kind. Instead of martial skills, their power derives from witchcraft. This talent develops through rigorous training in rituals designed to ensure that only the wiliest and deadliest spellcasters survive. Thankfully, they are also the fewest in number of all the major ratfolk clans.

The Red Witches were more heavily imprinted by the will and ways of their titan than any other slitherin breed. Physically the smallest of their race, they have rust- or ginger-colored fur. Their clan is matriarchal, consisting of female witches who take groups of lesser male warlocks, up to two dozen at a time, as covens. These covens seek out areas of magical power and establish underground lairs nearby. Their havens are filled with traps, illusions, and the witches' undead servitors. As they absorb and extract the local magical energy, the witches ingest various potions and powders intended to inspire prophetic visions. The resulting knowledge is called, collectively, the Gifts of Mormo.

The most powerful witch in each coven is called the Queen, in honor of the true Witch Queen Mormo. The Red Witches are unlike other ratfolk clans in another way as well: some lone Red Witches go off on their own to pursue research they do not care to share with the others. These individuals sometimes find their way into civilization, if that is where their visions take them.

A Red Witch slitherin is smaller than a human by more than a head, but it appears no less threatening for its small stature. A cunning, cruel intellect gleams in its red eyes, and it leers with a twisted smile. Reddish fur covers its body, except for its pink nose and long, hairless tail. Its sparse clothing is layered with pouches, and bits of arcane oddments poke from its leather belt.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Red Witch slitherin fight with magic, using {@condition charmed} or summoned monsters or animating undead to do the physical fighting for them. In most cases, though, unless a prophecy demands otherwise, they typically flee a superior force, using magic as required. Red Witches are the most intelligent, cunning, and subtle of the Unredeemed slitherin, and their stratagems reflect that fact.

trait.name: Feeding Frenzy
entries: A creature that is {@condition paralyzed} by a sour grub quickly becomes a target for other nearby grubs. If bitten while already {@condition paralyzed} a new saving throw is not required, but the creature's next saving throw is made with disadvantage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 poison damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 8} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn. Creatures that are immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition are immune to this effect.
A pale, fat wormlike creature as long as a large man's forearm wriggles free of a refuse heap, its jaws working feverishly as it searches for something living to feed upon.

entries.name: Useful Menace
entries: These vermin originally lived in the wilds, spawning in cesspits and stagnant pools or beneath the rotting carcasses of animals, but have found urban areas to be an even better habitat. Although disgusting and tenacious creatures, sour grubs do serve a purpose in many modern cities. Citizens tolerate them to a degree because the creatures eliminate disease-carrying rats and other vermin with a singular zeal.

entries.name: A Growing Problem
entries: Sour grubs are becoming an increasingly dangerous threat as cities of the Scarred Lands slowly rebuild, spread, and grow crowded, and cities such as Rahoch attract sour grubs in alarming quantities. Sewage drains, refuse piles, and even privies are infested. People who intrude upon sour grub nesting areas - which can be anywhere from gutters to back alleys to stables - are bitten and injected with a paralyzing poison.

Falling victim to this bite can make a person or animal a meal as other nearby grubs close to feed. Horrifically, some of the most destitute and desperate will sink to eating sour grub larvae, and some erstwhile rat-catchers become urban filth-farming maggot dealers.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The sour grub mindlessly attacks any creature it detects with 10 feet, although it will ignore other targets to feast on a {@condition paralyzed} creature. The grub cannot gain sustenance from creatures that are not flesh and blood (any construct, elemental, ooze, plant, or undead) and after making one successful attack against such a target it will seek other prey.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The spirit of the depths can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Corruption
entries: The spirit of the depths primarily feeds on the energy released by magical items as it corrupts them and makes them cursed versions of their original forms. The spirit of the lake will give out these cursed items as a ‘reward' to those it has {@condition charmed}.

action.name: Deceive
entries: The spirit of the depths can use its action to summon a {@spell programmed illusion} (spell save {@dc 19}) without the need of components. It usually uses this project a spirit form on top of the water's surface in order to communicate with visitors to the lake.

action.name: Demand
entries: The spirit of the depths can use its action to cast {@spell geas} (spell save {@dc 19}) as a 7th level spell without any components. If it targets a creature currently affected by its Deceive feature, that creature has disadvantage on the saving throw.

action.name: Consume
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 120 ft., one Medium or smaller target. {@h}the target is {@condition grappled} by pseudopod extended by the spirit of the depths (escape {@dc 15}) and dragged into the water. At the start of each turn the creature is dragged 30 feet closer to the spirit of the depths. Once it reaches the spirit, it is automatically engulfed. The engulfed creature can't breathe, is {@condition restrained}, and takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the spirit's turns. A {@condition grappled} or engulfed creature that is affected by the spirit's Deceive feature has disadvantage on its escape attempts, as the illusion makes the process seem much more pleasant.
{@i "So, despite the peasant's misgivings about the lake, I continued to seek for it, and the spirit that dwelt within." Jonald looked over the audience, they were enraptured, Too bad, he thought.}

{@i "After long journeys and many trials, I found the lake. And, at midnight, the spirit arose from the center of the lake, gleaming and beautiful. She reached out her hand to me and asked what I desired. I told her that I only wished to see her, and be able to tell others about her wisdom and generosity." Jonald had long given up on the compulsion that drove him to lie—he could only hope that some of these poor fools would not be inspired by his falsehoods.}

The true form of the spirit of the depths is an abomination that lies at the bottom of deep forest or mountain lakes. Its natural form is a slimy and amorphous dark green blob. However it is possessed of powerful and corruptive illusionary magic and it uses it to lure others into providing it more power.

entries.name: The Bounty of the Water
entries: At night, when it detects the presence of visitors, it projects a form that it believes will be most attractive to the petitioner(s). Using this form, it offers some arrangement: either a trade of a magical weapon for a more powerful one, or request for the creature to spread news about the lake and its guardian, or, if the visitor has little to offer, it simply compels the creature to come into the lake, where it can be {@condition grappled}, slain and consumed.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Spirits of the depths use their Deceive and Demand abilities to gather more power, but they are always careful and more ready to try and escape than fight against any determined opposition. If they realize that a group has seen through their illusions, they might recruit other weak-willed followers to defend them against their enemies.

monster.name: Steel Beetle
languages: understands the languages of its master but can't speak

trait.name: Crushing Claws
entries: A single target being {@condition grappled} by both claws only makes one escape roll, but does so with disadvantage.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The steel beetle has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Energy Dependence
entries: If the steel beetle has its hit point maximum reduced it is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The steel beetle makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, the steel beetle can automatically hit the target with its claw, and the steel beetle can't make attacks with this claw against other targets.
This beetle shaped automaton's steel carapace is stained with dried blood, as are the sharp edges of its two massive fore-claws. Its massive frame is easily as large as a grown horse.

entries.name: Reliable Servitors
entries: The steel beetles were built in the first half-century after the Titanswar by the magician Gest Ganest and his apprentices in their now abandoned workshop deep in the Kelder Mountains. Some were used as security for the workshop, but most were sold for hefty commissions to private individuals as bodyguards and war machines. Over the years, most of these constructs have worn out or been destroyed, but some have survived, either faithfully executing their last instructions or, more commonly, sitting inert, awaiting refueling.

entries.name: Necromantic Fuel
entries: Steel beetles fuel their powerful machinery with life energy, and only through the sacrifice of living beings can these devices be charged. The ritual, although there are few alive who still know it, also binds the beetle to the ritualist, and it will dutifully follow the instructions of whoever charges it. This necromancy leaves the beetle with a vulnerability, though: attacks that drain life energy can disrupt the dark magic that animates it.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The steel beetle follows instructions to the letter, which means its tactics will depend on the foresight of its master, and it won't adapt to the unexpected or show any creativity. In the absence of more specific instructions it will mindlessly attack the closest enemy and fight until destroyed.

trait.name: Cause Strife {@recharge}
entries: The strife elemental can use a bonus action to amplify emotions within 30 feet of itself. Each creature must make a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or become grumpy and difficult. Players should be encouraged to play out any source of conflict as being of utmost importance. The strife elemental will choose a time of conflict to utilize this feature: when parleying with potential enemies, haggling with a merchant, sneaking past enemies, arguing about existing conflicts within the group or dividing up treasure, for example.

trait.name: Impersonate
entries: When the strife elemental takes a long rest, it can choose a new identity. Its body and clothing reshape themselves to take on that identity, which can be any Small or Medium humanoid of any background. As part of the reshaping process, select up to four skills and two sets of tools for the strife elemental to become proficient with. Strife elementals prefer to avoid direct conflict but prove proficient with all simple and martial weapons if they cannot avoid a fight.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doelwit. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) doorborende schade.

These creatures appear as perfectly ordinary folk, going about their lives in a normal fashion, though conflict does seem to follow in their wake. They seem perfectly normal, except that, sometimes, when it thinks no one else is looking, it smiles cruelly to itself.

entries.name: Born of the Titanswar
entries: Sages speculate that strife elementals arise spontaneously from areas of great conflict and it is believed that all current strife elementals were born during the Divine War. Now they travel the lands, drawn like moths to a flame to any area of disquiet or seething conflict that is waiting to explode into open warfare.

entries.name: A New Guise
entries: Strife elementals have the ability to take on new personas, in order to further conflict without being instantly discovered. When they take on a new identity, they leave most of the old identity behind, meaning that they are hard to hold accountable for their actions. There is only one consistence to their personality, they are always contentious and capricious.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Strife elementals love to create fights but they try hard to avoid being caught in the middle of one. If taking a military disguise, they prefer to be an archer or a member of the command staff so that they can witness their achievements at a distance. In the worst case, strife elementals can use any weapon proficiently, so they will find something to defend themselves with.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The sundered woman's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}). The dryad can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The sundered woman has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The sundered woman's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The sundered woman can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts and Plants
entries: The sundered woman can communicate with beasts and plants as if they shared a language.

trait.name: Tree Stride
entries: Once on her turn, the sundered woman can use 10 feet of her movement to step magically into one living tree within her reach and emerge from a second living tree within 60 feet of the first tree, appearing in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the second tree. Both trees must be Large or bigger.

action.name: Wounding Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage. The target cannot recover hit points lost by this strike until it takes a short or long rest.

reaction.name: Lithe
entries: On a successful attack roll, the sundered woman can make a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check with the result of the attack roll as its DC. On a success, the sundered woman takes no damage from the hit.

From a distance, these creatures appear to be beautiful women, nymphs or hamadryads. Up close, one sees that deep wounds mar their flesh. Their injuries do not bleed, though, and their flesh rejoins and splits in new places as they move. Most sundered women seem oblivious to their grotesque appearance. They tend to wander lost in the forest, searching for the one tree that is their partner but never finding it. Anyone or anything that gets in their way or interferes with their search is subject to their wrath.

Sundered women vary widely in personality and purpose. Some are little more than agents of destruction, bent on inflicting harm on whatever they encounter. Others seem kindly, but tend to break at the first moment of stress.

entries.name: War Victims
entries: Some of the oldest children of the forest still suffer from the titan's influence over the world, even all these years after the creators' defeat. Throughout the Scarred Lands, wherever titanspawn or the lords' own hands have afflicted magical woods, dryad-kin have suffered. Where forests have been leveled, charred or corrupted by unholy influence, they have been driven to madness. Kept alive by some cruel twist of fate or unknowable will, the refugee fey have been twisted into a mockery of their former beauty. Without the trees to which they were bound, the wood spirits suffer a confused, wrathful and wretched existence, ostracized from their homes and forced to exist alone and afraid.

entries.name: Beyond the Forest
entries: It is even possible to encounter one of these lost women outside the woodlands. This creature is the saddest of all, however, because her forest home has been completely decimated, or she has become so lost that she no longer knows where her home might be. These individuals are perhaps the most dangerous sundered women, for they have lost all bearing on the reality they once knew. Unfortunately, they might also be the only ones who could relate the fate that befell their homes, and what has become of any titanspawn responsible. Sundered women can also be vastly knowledgeable of the world around which their trees grew and may speak of events hundreds of years past—if they can be communicated with and understood.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Sundered women tend to avoid direct combat or even ignore the presence of others—until the search for their home is interfered with, when they can lash out. Others seek to lure intruders into traps to find out if {@i these} foreigners were the ones who destroyed the local forest. When attacking, they prefer thick forests where they can dart from the cover of one tree to the next, using their {@i nimble escape} and {@i tree stride} features together.

trait.name: Sure-Footed
entries: The sutak has advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sutak makes two flail attacks.

action.name: Flail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

Fierce and cruel, the sutak are among the most aggressive of the titanspawn remaining in the Scarred Lands. Sutak organize into nomadic clans, each led by a powerful and ruthless chieftain. Feuds and petty rivalries are common among them, often triggered by competition for the meager resources of the Ukrudan as well as by violent clannish politics. Alliances in the interests of a common goal are short-lived, much to the relief of the human settlements along the edges of the desert.

A sutak, like its ironbred brethren, has the upper body of a well-muscled human covered in a very short coat of rust-colored fur. Its legs are like a horse's, ending in hooves, and its horrible, emaciated head is also similar to that of a horse or a donkey.

entries.name: Spawn of Thulkas
entries: Favored children of Thulkas, the sutak were decimated during the final years of the Titanswar. In the aftermath of their patron's fall, the remnants of the race escaped the fury of the divine races by retreating into the fiery reaches of the Ukrudan Desert. From there, the sutak prey upon merchant caravans plying the trade routes between Chardunahae and the kingdoms to the east, and they erupt from the desert sporadically on far-ranging rampages to sate their lust for plunder and revenge.

The sutak continue to worship the Father of Fire. Fire-mages and sorcerers fill the cultural role of priests for their tribes, and many of their leading warriors bear ceremonial tattoos that they make using molten metal instead of ink. A mighty sutak chieftain's chest, face, and arms are covered with designs of gleaming bronze or gold that pronounce his devotion to the Iron Titan.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Sutak warriors are well organized and disciplined. At the first sign of danger, they will launch their javelins at the enemy and then close to attack with their flails. They do not hesitate to use their surefootedness as another advantage, often moving onto terrain that is treacherous for less adept warriors.

trait.name: Swamp Camouflage
entries: The tar beetle has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in marshy terrain.

action.name: Mandibles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doel. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) snijschade.

action.name: Tar Spray {@recharge 5}
entries: The tar beetle sprays out a 15-foot cone of sticky tar. Creatures within the cone must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw or become {@condition restrained}. A creature can spend its action to escape the tar or to help another creature remove the tar.

The tar beetle is a voracious and stealthy marsh-dwelling predator commonly found in the swamps of Khan Thet. Typically hunting in clusters of two to five individuals, the beetles lie partially submerged in pools that have been overgrown with vegetation, which makes the beetles difficult to detect. Upon sensing prey, they spray a cone of tar, attempting to immobilize the victim to a point where it can be overwhelmed easily.

entries.name: Adapted for the Swamp
entries: The tar beetle has a dark-green chitinous shell with dozens of spine-like growths clustered along its back. These spines - which normally resting flush against the beetle's shell, but that stand erect when the insect is submerged - serve as breathing tubes. The coloring of the spines also provides natural camouflage when the beetle is hunting; with much of its body concealed under the murky water, a tar beetle resembles another clump of marsh grass.
Solitary males are commonly encountered during the spring mating season, and they are extremely aggressive. They attack any trespassers that intrude on their hunting ground.

entries.name: Tar Nests
entries: The beetles build large nests of mud, twigs, branches and rotting vegetation held together by their tar, which rise like small hills amid swamp waters. Each nest contains tunnels that lead to larva chambers and waste and storage pits, and each nest supports up to 20 beetles, including an egg-laying queen. Tar beetle larvae hatch during the summer and require a month to grow to maturity, during which time they are fed dead or immobilized prey, which are kept in the storage pits. If the nest is threatened, the queen and half of the adults put up a fierce defense while the remaining beetles carry larvae to safety.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The tar beetle sprays a cone of tar at its prey and then scuttles rapidly from its hiding place to attack with two pincers. Its mandibles are extremely sharp and are equally effective at cutting through armor or flesh. Tar beetles rarely attack if outnumbered unless trespassers wander too close to their nest. When attacking multiple opponents, beetles ignore immobilized individuals, concentrating on active opponents when possible. Any trapped prey is later dragged back to the beetles' nest.

monster.name: Tattooed Corpse
languages: understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Tattoos
entries: The corpse has {@dice 1d3 + 1} magical tattoos and can use its bonus action to activate a tattoo. The effects of the tattoos are given in the chart below, some tattoos can be used more than once a day, otherwise the corpse must take a long rest before using that tattoo again.

rows: The corpse's Strength becomes 17 (+3) and its Dexterity becomes 12 (+1). Its slam attack becomes {@hit 5} to hit and 6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage. If it has a longsword, that attack becomes {@hit 5} to hit and either 7 ({@dice 1d8 + 3}) or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage. Its armor class becomes 11. This effect lasts for four hours.
The corpse gains the immediate benefit of the {@spell stoneskin} spell, but does not need to concentrate upon the magical effect.

The corpse makes a breath weapon attack as if it were a dragonborn of a specific ancestry (the ancestry is chosen when the tattoo is created and cannot be changed). The attack is {@dc 13} and does {@damage 3d6} damage.
The corpse adds 16 ({@damage 3d10}) lightning damage to a successful melee attack.
The corpse gains the benefit of {@spell enhance ability}, the effect is preselected when the tattoo is created and it does not need to concentrate to maintain the magical effect.
The corpse's melee attacks become magical for ten minutes.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: Als de bloedzombie door de schade tot 0 hit points wordt gereduceerd, moet hij een grondwetsredding doen met een DC van 5 + de opgelopen schade, tenzij de schade radiant is of het gevolg van een critical hit. Als hij slaagt, heeft de zombie nog maar 1 hit.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) slashing damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d10 + 1}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doel. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) knuppelschade.

The sorceresses of Albadia are acknowledged as experts in the arcane practice of tattoo magic. What is less known is the darker side of this skill, in which the sorceresses combine forces with necromancers or tribal shamans to inscribe enchanted tattoos upon reanimated corpses. Special skills must be used to inscribe the marks on their flesh and an individual tattooed corpse can bear 1-4 tattoos. Lifeless zombies suffer no side effects from using these tattoos.

entries.name: Guards for Hire
entries: These enhanced zombies are often sold to wealthy clients for use as guards. As they tend to be expensive (1,000-6,000 gp each), such zombies are often dressed in armor or tunics. The creation of these creatures is viewed with horror by followers of the good-aligned gods, who consider it blasphemous, especially when the sacred symbols of their deities are used as tattoo marks. Ancient tattooed corpses, created generations ago, are sometimes encountered in ruins or the wilderness, still attempting to carry out their duties even after their masters have perished.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Tattooed corpses are often equipped with weapons, which they are capable of clumsily wielding. Tattooed corpses guard the place or individual that they are assigned to and utilize the abilities inherent in their tattoos as needed.

trait.name: Sheltering Wings
entries: As an action, a tent bird can lift and spread its wings, creating a tentlike dome around itself large enough to include 1 Medium or 2 Small creatures. Creatures within are protected from any normal desert weather, and also share the bird's resistance to fire.

trait.name: Subsonic Call
entries: If trapped beneath the desert sands, a tent bird emits a throaty subsonic call. The sound is audible up to a quarter mile away, and all tent birds, even wild ones, will respond to the call and attempt to dig out a trapped bird.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tent bird makes one bite attack and two talon attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} om te raken, reikwijdte 5 ft., één doel. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) snijschade.

action.name: Talon
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) slashing damage.

The tent bird is a tall creature, with pure white feathers and heavy, well-muscled legs with shovel-like feet, it is built like a flightless bird. Although in some ways it resembles an ostrich, the tent bird's wings are large and well-feathered, and as the creature settles down to rest these wings fold up in an odd manner.

entries.name: Desert Striders
entries: Few mounts are more valued among the tribesmen of the Desert of Onn than the tent bird. It is hardy, needs little water to survive, remains perfectly happy consuming lizards and cacti for nourishment, and crosses the sands without complaint on its two mighty legs. Yet Ubantu tribesmen prize these birds most highly for their large wings.

entries.name: Shelter from the Storm
entries: Though the birds are flightless, their wings nevertheless serve an important function: When a sandstorm threatens, the tent bird crouches down and folds its wings around itself, like a tent. With sturdy wings locked in place like a domed canopy, it safely weathers the deadly storm. Its remarkable physiology maintains the temperature within its wings at a level comfortable for beasts and humans, as well as allowing it to support a tremendous weight of sand. In the wild, the tent bird uses this ability to protect its chicks, but a well-trained bird will do the same for its rider.

entries.name: Untouched by Flame
entries: The bird also secretes a fire-resistant oil that permeates its feathers, giving it excellent protection from fire. So beloved are the tent birds by some Ubantu that they ask that their mount pass with them into death; Ubantu chiefs traditionally pass into the afterlife with their tent bird's wings protecting them as the funeral pyre catches flame.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The wild tent bird is not aggressive, and will generally only fight to if unable to flee, or to protect its young. Captive birds can be trained to fight, though, much like a warhorse.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the thulkan or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The thulkan sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The thulkan makes two warhammer attacks.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, or 21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage if used in two hands, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Flaming Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage.

Thulkans are one of the few races that the Iron Father, Thulkas, created intentionally. He drew these monstrosities from his iron cauldron and shaped them into living smiths to churn out mighty magical weapons for the Divine War. No one knows how many thulkans yet remain, but their numbers have certainly dwindled in the era after the Titanswar.

A thulkan is a fiery creature seemingly composed of rock and magma, glowing with a dreadful heat. Its giant, humanoid body is strangely featureless and sexless, with a marbled black rocky hide that's constantly cooling and reheating. Its white-hot eyes seethe with hatred and power.

entries.name: Consummate Artisans
entries: Thulkans are gifted in most crafts, but especially cunning with metalwork, able to forge nearly any weapon, suit of armor, jeweled treasure, or device. They are also skilled at enchanting such items, even though they are not themselves spellcasters. However, they are also fond of placing subtle curses on the items they create.

entries.name: Craven Recluses
entries: Despite their considerable power, thulkans are greedy and selfish, and they cherish life far more than they do material things or victory in combat. They are likely to barter their way out of a defeat by offering to create magic items in exchange for double the amount of raw materials required.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Thulkans rarely join in combat, and often flee as soon as they can, or try to negotiate with their enemies. If necessary they will attack with their warhammer until the foe retreats, in which case they will use flaming rocks to cover their own retreat.

monster.name: Thunder Orb

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but does not speak

trait.name: Lightning Absorption
entries: If the thunder orb receives lightning damage, it takes no damage and instead gains temporary hit points equal to the damage amount.

action.name: Lightning
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) lightning damage.

action.name: Grand Lightning (Recharge 5-6)
entries: Each creature in a line 100 feet long and 5 feet wide originating from the orb must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

reaction.name: Free-floating
entries: When struck by a melee attack, the thunder orb can move half its speed without provoking an opportunity attack.
